title: Pat Storey
text:
Patricia Storey (née Shaw; born 30 March 1960) is an Irish <a href="Anglicanism">Anglican</a> bishop. Since 2013, she has been the <a href="Diocese%20of%20Meath%20and%20Kildare">Bishop of Meath and Kildare</a> in the <a href="Church%20of%20Ireland">Church of Ireland</a>. She was the first woman to become a bishop in the Church of Ireland and the <a href="Ordination%20of%20women%20in%20the%20Anglican%20Communion">first woman to be an Anglican</a>bishop in <a href="British%20Isles">Ireland and Great Britain</a>.
Early life and education.
Storey was born 30 March 1960. She was educated at the <a href="Methodist%20College%20Belfast">Methodist College Belfast</a>, a <a href="grammar%20school">grammar school</a> in Belfast, Northern Ireland.
She studied French and English at <a href="Trinity%20College%2C%20Dublin">Trinity College, Dublin</a>, graduating with a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1983; as per tradition, her BA was later promoted to a <a href="Master%20of%20Arts%20%28Oxbridge%20and%20Dublin%29">Master of Arts</a> (MA Dubl) degree. In 1994, she began to train for ordination at the <a href="Church%20of%20Ireland%20Theological%20College">Church of Ireland Theological College</a>. She graduated in 1997 with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Theology">Bachelor of Theology</a> (BTh) degree.
Ordained ministry.
Storey was ordained in the <a href="Church%20of%20Ireland">Church of Ireland</a> as <a href="deacon">deacon</a> in 1997 and priest in 1998. From 1997 to 2000, she served her <a href="Curate%23Anglican%20Communion">curacy</a> in the Parish of Kilconriola and Ballyclug, (<a href="Ballymena">Ballymena</a>), County Antrim. From 2000 to 2004, she was an assistant curate at St Aidan's Church, <a href="Glenavy">Glenavy</a>, County Antrim. In 2004, she was appointed <a href="Rector%20%28ecclesiastical%29">rector</a> of St Augustine's Church, <a href="Derry">Derry</a>, County Londonderry.
Episcopal ministry.
On 19 September 2013, Storey was chosen by the House of Bishops to succeed <a href="Richard%20Clarke%20%28bishop%29">Richard Clarke</a> as <a href="Bishop%20of%20Meath%20and%20Kildare">Bishop of Meath and Kildare</a>. She was consecrated to the episcopate at <a href="Christ%20Church%20Cathedral%2C%20Dublin">Christ Church Cathedral, Dublin</a>, on 30 November 2013. She is the first woman to be elected as a bishop in the Church of Ireland and the first woman to be an <a href="Anglican%20Communion">Anglican</a> bishop in Ireland and Great Britain.
As Bishop of Meath and Kildare, she is the only Anglican bishop who is not also an <a href="archbishop">archbishop</a> or <a href="Primate%20%28bishop%29">primate</a> to be styled "<a href="Most%20Reverend">The Most Reverend</a>" (rather than "<a href="Right%20Reverend">The Right Reverend</a>"), the style usually restricted to archbishops or primates.
Views.
Storey has described her <a href="churchmanship">churchmanship</a> as "<a href="open%20evangelical">open</a> <a href="Liberal%20Christianity">liberal</a> <a href="evangelical">evangelical</a>". She was previously a board member of the <a href="Evangelical%20Alliance">Evangelical Alliance</a>. She voted 'no' on <a href="Same-sex%20marriage%20in%20the%20Republic%20of%20Ireland">same-gender marriage in Ireland</a> but, at the same time, affirmed <a href="Civil%20Partnership%20and%20Certain%20Rights%20and%20Obligations%20of%20Cohabitants%20Act%202010">civil unions and partnerships for same-gender couples</a> thus taking a middle of the road approach. In her words, "I believe that civil partnerships give gay people clear civil rights and recognition as people committed to one another, and I fully endorse this. ... However, I do not think this requires the redefinition of marriage to uphold it, and I do not believe marriage should be redefined.".
Personal life.
Storey is married to an Anglican priest, Earl Storey. Together they have two adult children; Luke and Carolyn.
